title: During World War 1 and World War 2, where were landing craft stored when in transit? - Quora

response.answer_text: WWII saw the development of specialized landing craft for assault of hostile beaches. The most famous of these was the 36′ Higgin’s Boat, or LCVP. An Attack Transport (APA) could carry about 20 of these plus two 50′ LCM’s which were capable of carrying a tank. The boats were (1) carried in Whelan Davits, each davit stored 2–3 boats. The rest of the boats were stored in cradle on hatch tops and lowered overboard by the ships cranes.  A ship model of a WWII APA with a partial load of landing craft.

There were no such thing as landing craft in WW1, at Gallipoli for example the men were landed by rowing boat or in one case an old ship was beached. In WW2 specialist landing craft wee carried on a larger ship, in the US Navy known as an attack transport.
